title: Establishing a Collaborative Framework for Dealing with the Impact of New Immigration
abstractText:
Since the 2004 expansion of the EU, the West Sussex coastal strip has witnessed immigration at an unprecedented pace and scale, adding perhaps 8,000 migrants to a local population of 254,000. Local evidence supports national findings that migrant numbers ebb and flow seasonally; some only staying in the country for a few months, with intentions about settlement changeable and varying widely.

There are several immediate consequences:

  • growth and vibrancy of certain local businesses;
  • shortage of appropriate housing;
  • additional communication issues for public agencies;
  • local hostility based upon myths about rising burdens on health care and education; and
  • uncertainty about future developments and their implications for provision.

The project aims to

  • Extend the impact of existing research in collaboration with local agencies and hence improve service delivery;
  • Share knowledge and experience held by employers, employment agencies, Gangmasters Authority, employees and others, (to be achieved by collaborative meetings, targeted training and briefings, contributing to public information publications, involvement with planning and forecasting debates);
  • Develop sensitive mapping and monitoring of nationality/ethnicity/language more effectively; and
  • Extend and share knowledge of the range of specific needs for EAL;
    Contribute to raising the level of local stakeholder awareness about immigration patterns and trends.
